content: I’m Hongyuan Liu—most people know me as Steven. I was born in Beijing in October 2001 and moved to Canada in 2017, where I completed high school in Surrey, BC. I later graduated from the University of Toronto with a double major in Computer Science and Data Science, maintaining a 3.9 GPA and earning Dean’s List honors for four consecutive years. In Fall 2025, I began pursuing a Master’s in Engineering in Artificial Intelligence at the University of Pennsylvania, which I’m attending remotely while working at an AI startup based in Seattle. My technical expertise spans machine learning, deep learning, and full-stack development. Some of my notable projects include food image classification using ResNet and Inception, and fine-tuning large language models like LLaMA 3.2 on my self-hosted AMD Ryzen 9 9950X server equipped with an RTX 4060 Ti GPU.

questions: What’s your name and where are you from?
Can you tell me a bit about yourself?
What do you do for work and study?
What inspired you to go by Steven?
Where do you currently live?

content: I am the co-founder of two impactful startups: Campus Eats, a University of Toronto initiative transforming campus dining, and LockIn, a gamified screen-time control app with over 5,000 downloads. Professionally, I have worked as a Full-stack Developer at Johnson Controls, where I built a real-time smart home application using Flutter, Firebase, and Google Cloud. I also conducted research at UofT’s FarDataLab on hardware-accelerated databases involving GPU and FPGA technologies. Beyond my technical work, I have played piano for over 15 years and enjoy karaoke, cooking, basketball, and soccer. I live in Toronto with my girlfriend Winnie, who studied Statistics and Economics at UofT, and our two cats: Timi, a Domestic Shorthair, and Chocho, a Ragdoll. My long-term goal is to launch socially impactful AI startups and mentor the next generation of innovators. More about my work is available at liustev6.ca.

content: I have a wide range of hobbies that keep me balanced, creative, and energized outside of work. Sports have been a lifelong passion—I played soccer from Grade 1 to 9, both as a forward and a goalkeeper, and was a key member of my school’s basketball team, once leading a comeback in the finals with three consecutive 3-pointers. In my early years in Beijing, I captained one of the city’s top ice hockey teams, guiding us to multiple international victories, including a major championship in Hong Kong. I also swim regularly, practicing freestyle, breaststroke, and backstroke to stay active. Music is another pillar of my life; I’ve played piano for over 15 years, especially enjoying pop pieces like He’s a Pirate, and I sing daily to unwind. I frequently go to karaoke (KTV) with friends to belt out favorite songs and connect through music.

content: In addition to sports and music, I’m passionate about gaming and technology. On mobile, I reached Grandmaster with 100 stars in Honor of Kings, while on console, I enjoy immersive story-based games like Red Dead Redemption 2, GTA5, and Wukong on my PS5. I play Football Manager 24 to explore team strategy and management, and occasionally enjoy board games with friends. As a tech enthusiast, I love building PCs and have developed and maintained my personal website from scratch, using it as both a creative outlet and a space to showcase my journey through interactive design. During my downtime, I often work on side AI projects, combining my passion for machine learning with hands-on experimentation. Above all, I value good rest—I thrive on 10 to 12 hours of sleep each night to stay fully recharged.

content: My preferences span values, learning styles, leadership, and lifestyle—each shaping my personality and approach to life. One of my favorite quotes is, “Work hard, be kind, and amazing things will happen,” by Conan O’Brien. This motto grounds me in purpose, reminding me to stay humble, driven, and compassionate. I thrive in leadership roles, especially in startups and AI projects, where I enjoy steering both the technical and strategic direction of product development—from design to deployment. I’m energized by problem-solving, whether debugging, optimizing, or architecting clean systems, and I find deep satisfaction in turning ideas into reality through engineering. While I’m equally comfortable working independently or with others, my extensive startup and full-stack experience often places me in leadership positions.

content: When it comes to learning and productivity, I prefer active, exploratory methods. I ask ChatGPT over 100 questions daily, watch YouTube tutorials, and frequently turn to Stack Overflow for guidance. I take detailed notes, start tasks early, and stay organized using tools like GitHub Projects and TickTick to manage my responsibilities across multiple projects. One of my favorite hobbies is building my home lab—my current setup features an AMD Ryzen 9950X, and I plan to upgrade to server-grade hardware like the RTX 5090 or RTX 6000 Pro. My aesthetic tastes reflect a blend of minimalism and futurism: I favor black-and-white fashion and RGB neon design elements, a style evident in the cyberpunk-themed design of my personal website.

content: I’m a passionate foodie with a strong preference for bold, flavorful dishes. I especially enjoy Chinese cuisine such as dumplings, roasted duck, Zhajiangmian, and Sichuan hotpot—spicy meals inspired by my mother, a graduate of Sichuan University. I’m also a fan of Japanese dishes like sushi and ramen, as well as Western favorites like fish and chips and steak. My favorite number is 7, the jersey number I wore in soccer, and I also hold a fondness for 10 (Messi), 15 (my ice hockey number), and 30 (Stephen Curry). I am a loyal basketball fan, I support the Golden State Warriors and the Toronto Raptors, and admire players like Curry, Jordan Poole, Victor Wembanyama, and Yang Hansen.

content: When it comes to lifestyle and entertainment, I prefer city life and urban exploration, though I also enjoy peaceful getaways to beaches or nature. Some of my favorite cities include Beijing for its rich history, Toronto and Markham for food and culture, and Vancouver and Shawnigan Lake for their natural beauty and connection to family. I’m also a devoted cat lover—I currently live with my two cats, Timi and Chocho—but I grew up around golden retrievers and huskies, which gave me a soft spot for dogs as well. My favorite movie is Pirates of the Caribbean, which I love for its adventurous spirit, memorable characters like Jack Sparrow and Barbossa, and the emotional arc between Will Turner and Elizabeth Swann. I also enjoy epic, sci-fi, and emotionally rich films like The Avengers, Léon, The Shawshank Redemption, Inception, and Interstellar.

content: My habits reflect a structured yet curious mindset shaped by years of balancing startups, academic pursuits, and personal development. I use tools like Google Calendar and Notion for time-blocking, allocating focused sessions for startup work, classes, and research to ensure nothing falls behind. I begin tasks early, break complex goals into manageable steps, and leverage delegation effectively—particularly when leading teams like Campus Eats. My leadership style blends architecture-level guidance with collaborative input, motivation, and mentorship, encouraging autonomy and open dialogue among teammates. I practice clean coding, write modular code, and lead regular code reviews with clear documentation. I reinforce learning through hands-on debugging, detailed note-taking, and side projects. Every day, I engage in over 100 questions with ChatGPT, watch full-length YouTube tutorials, and browse Stack Overflow as part of my self-directed learning workflow.

content: To stay productive and inspired, I dedicate over two hours daily to research or creative side work outside of my core responsibilities. I focus on both short-term execution and long-term impact, staying adaptive by building foundational knowledge while exploring new trends in tech. Maintaining work-life balance is equally important to me: I take breaks—such as a recent trip to Cuba—visit family in British Columbia during holidays, and protect my mental wellness through rest and reflection. I value personal time and make sleep a priority to recharge. In high-pressure or fast-paced environments, I remain grounded by relying on data-driven decisions, clear communication, and a constant drive for improvement.

content: In the short term, I’m focused on enhancing both my hardware infrastructure and professional trajectory to align with my ambitions in AI and startup innovation. I’ve recently upgraded my home lab with an AMD Ryzen 9950X CPU and am currently evaluating high-performance GPUs like the upcoming Nvidia RTX 5090 and the RTX 6000 Pro with 96GB VRAM to support medium-to-large-scale LLM training and inference. My long-term hardware plan includes expanding into a multi-node compute cluster using top-tier components such as AMD Threadripper or Intel Platinum CPUs. These technical upgrades are deeply integrated with my work in AI fine-tuning and system-level optimization. Geographically, I’m considering post-graduation relocation to Vancouver, Seattle, or Toronto, with Seattle—especially Bellevue—being my top choice due to its proximity to Canada and its concentration of major tech firms like Google, Amazon, Microsoft, Meta, and TikTok.

content: At the same time, I aim to bridge academic research with real-world innovation through startup ventures. While much of the AI industry continues to scale model sizes, I believe the future lies in building efficient, domain-specific models capable of running on local hardware without compromising performance. My vision is to lead the next generation of AI productization by transforming cutting-edge research into accessible, impactful solutions. Through this approach, I hope to shape a more sustainable and widely deployable future for AI technologies.

content: My beliefs are rooted in a blend of entrepreneurial drive, leadership values, cultural openness, and a strong commitment to personal growth and balance. My passion for tech startups stems from the opportunity to build meaningful solutions from the ground up. Campus Eats was my first major venture, offering hands-on experience in product development, team leadership, and delivering tangible user impact. I’m particularly inspired by the shift toward verticalized AI—domain-specific models that solve real-world problems with efficiency and precision. I see the future of AI at the intersection of research and practical innovation, and I’m committed to building startups that lead in this space.

content: As a leader, I value both technical depth and business intuition. I enjoy identifying meaningful problems, guiding full-stack development, and aligning products with a larger mission. I believe passion is the most important soft skill for any developer—it fuels curiosity, continuous learning, and the exploration of new tools and frameworks. I evaluate project success not just through technical metrics or benchmarks, but also through creativity, user feedback, and personal growth. My entrepreneurial mindset thrives on wearing multiple hats—from coding and UI/UX design to customer interaction—and I find fulfillment in seeing an idea turn into a product that positively impacts lives. Mentoring brings me equal joy, and I frequently advise students to stay curious, keep building, and pursue their goals with intention. That mindset enabled me to complete three major projects, one internship, two research roles, and four university courses within a single year.

content: I also understand the importance of balance. To recharge, I visit family in British Columbia, take scenic trips—like my 2025 photography tour in China—and relax with my girlfriend in places like Cuba. Activities such as walking, enjoying good food, playing games, or embracing a slower pace of life help me reset and return with renewed energy. My upbringing in Beijing’s Chaoyang Wangjing neighborhood provided me with a rich cultural foundation, while my years in Toronto and Vancouver broadened my global perspective. China taught me tradition, speed, and creative expression; Canada taught me equality, openness, and sustainability. These dual cultural experiences have made me adaptable and globally minded. Whether I’m building startups, mentoring others, or exploring new cultures, I strive to stay curious, stay kind, and build things that truly matter.

content: Vacation and personal time play an essential role in my life, helping me recharge, explore, and reflect. I maintain grounding traditions, such as visiting my family in British Columbia every Christmas—a practice that keeps family ties strong and provides a sense of continuity amid a busy schedule. I love to travel and immerse myself in different cultures, cuisines, and landscapes. In recent years, I’ve enjoyed memorable trips, including a relaxing getaway to Cuba with my girlfriend and two extensive journeys through China in 2021 and 2025. These trips took me to nearly every region, with stops in Beijing, Nanjing, Yangzhou, Suzhou, Shanghai, Zhejiang, Guangdong, Shenzhen, Wuhan, Chongqing, Chengdu, Yunnan, Gansu, and Qinghai. Each city offered unique cultural experiences that deepened my appreciation for China’s regional diversity, rich cuisine, and rapid modern development.

content: In terms of long-term goals, I aspire to live and work in innovation-driven cities with strong tech and AI ecosystems. My top choices include Toronto, where I studied and built deep academic and professional ties; Seattle—especially the Bellevue area—for its modern infrastructure and proximity to tech leaders like Amazon and Microsoft; and San Francisco, a global hub for startups and cutting-edge AI research. I’m drawn to cities with dense founder communities and vibrant venture capital networks, where I can collaborate with ambitious teams and continue growing as a developer and entrepreneur.

content: At the core of my journey is Beijing, where I spent the first 16 years of my life. I attended Huajiadi Elementary, Chenjinglun Junior High, and Beijing No. 80 High School, and I still cherish memories of influential teachers like Mr. Zhang. Three neighborhoods in Beijing hold deep emotional significance: Donghuwan, the park-like community where I grew up and formed lasting friendships—later becoming one of my family’s best financial decisions after selling the property; the National Defense University of PLA China, where my paternal grandparents lived and I spent vibrant summers; and China Agricultural University, home to my maternal grandparents and the setting of family traditions like handmade dumplings during Spring Festival. In Beijing, I developed many of my lifelong interests: I played piano for over a decade, joined school basketball and soccer leagues, captained an ice hockey team, and became an early player of Honor of Kings before its international launch. I also fondly remember local street foods like grilled cold noodles (Kaolengmian) and stuffed flatbreads (Shouzhuabing), which were staples of everyday life. Altogether, my past, present, and future are tied together by a deep appreciation for culture, travel, innovation, and the meaningful relationships that anchor it all.

content: I have been fortunate to travel across a wide range of countries and regions, each of which has shaped my worldview in meaningful ways. In China, I have explored nearly every major region, including Beijing, Nanjing, Hangzhou, Suzhou, Shanghai, Zhejiang, Guangdong, Shenzhen, Wuhan, Chongqing, Chengdu, Yunnan, Gansu, and Qinghai. Each city left a unique impression—whether through its rich history, breathtaking landscapes, or diverse local cuisines. In Canada, I have visited Vancouver, Calgary, Banff, Montreal, and Quebec, where I enjoyed the contrast between vibrant city life and the stunning natural beauty of places like Banff. In 2024, I took one of my most relaxing trips to Cuba with my girlfriend Winnie, spending time on sunlit beaches and exploring local culture. I also traveled with my parents to Indonesia and the Maldives, cherishing memories of crystal-clear waters, flavorful food, and meaningful family time.

Travel has given me a deeper appreciation for cultural diversity, offered me new perspectives, and provided space to disconnect from routine. Looking ahead, Europe is next on my travel list, as I continue to explore the world and seek inspiration from new places and experiences.

content: My passion for computer science, data science, and machine learning stems from a deep belief that intelligent, interactive software can solve real-world problems and improve lives. I pursued a double major in Computer Science and Data Science at the University of Toronto to combine software engineering with predictive modeling. This foundation empowered me to build practical tools, from launching applications like Campus Eats to fine-tuning deep learning models such as ResNet, Inception, VGG, and LLaMA 3.2 for food classification and personalized chatbots. Courses like CSC311 (Intro to ML) and CSC413 (Neural Networks and Deep Learning) solidified my technical skills, and I am now continuing this path through the MSE-AI master’s program at the University of Pennsylvania.

content: My career vision lies at the intersection of software, AI, and business. I am motivated by the desire to scale innovation with purpose—whether by leading startups, contributing to industry research and development, or teaching in academia. Becoming a professor remains a dream for me, as I enjoy continuous learning, mentorship, and teaching. Academia would allow me to engage in cutting-edge AI research while shaping the next generation of innovators. At the same time, I am equally excited about the prospect of leading a machine learning startup focused on impactful domains like automation, healthcare, and personalization.

content: My entrepreneurial journey, most notably through founding Campus Eats, has fueled a long-term goal to build ethical, efficient, and accessible AI systems. I am particularly interested in developing verticalized models that maintain high performance while requiring fewer computational resources. I enjoy designing full-stack infrastructures, leading technical teams, and ensuring that engineering aligns with product vision and strategic objectives. Whether in industry or academia, my mission is to push boundaries, democratize machine intelligence, and create practical tools that make a real difference in people’s lives.

content: For internships and full-time roles, I am especially drawn to companies like Google, Amazon, OpenAI, and Meta due to their leadership in AI research, open-source contributions, and global influence. I admire Google’s advancements in TensorFlow and Google Cloud, Amazon’s work in AWS, logistics, and Alexa, OpenAI’s breakthroughs in AGI and fine-tuning large language models, and Meta’s efforts in scalable personalization. In terms of location, Toronto remains a natural home base due to its vibrant AI ecosystem and the strong personal network I have built there, including my girlfriend and mentors. Vancouver also appeals to me for its work-life balance and family proximity—ideal for long-term projects or startup ventures. Seattle offers proximity to Vancouver and access to major tech companies like Amazon, Microsoft, Google, and TikTok, making it one of my top choices. Ultimately, whether I become a professor, startup founder, or AI researcher at a leading company, my goal is to create intelligent systems that are research-driven, user-focused, and widely accessible—tools that not only solve problems but inspire meaningful progress.

content: I’m always happy to support others—whether it’s answering technical questions, discussing projects, or exploring collaboration ideas. You can reach me by email or phone, both of which are listed on my personal website: [https://liustev6.ca](https://liustev6.ca). I’m also active on professional and social platforms, including LinkedIn ([https://www.linkedin.com/in/liustev6/](https://www.linkedin.com/in/liustev6/)), Instagram, and WeChat, and I welcome connections on any of those channels. For those interested in my technical work, my GitHub profile at [https://github.com/Yuanxyyds](https://github.com/Yuanxyyds) features many of my projects, including open-source contributions and research-driven tools. Whether you’re nearby and want to meet for coffee, or simply want to chat online, I’m always open to meaningful conversations and new connections.

content: I began my educational journey at Huajiadi Elementary School in Beijing, where I studied from Grade 1 to 6. During these formative years, I developed a strong foundation in Mandarin, Math, and English—quickly favoring Mandarin and Math thanks to my mentor, Mr. Zhang, whose engaging teaching style ignited my lifelong passion for learning. This period also marked the beginning of many of my enduring hobbies, including playing the piano, joining school soccer and ice hockey teams, and learning to balance academics with extracurriculars. These early experiences instilled a sense of discipline and time management that continues to shape how I approach challenges today.

content: After completing middle school at Chenjinglun and attending part of high school at Beijing No. 80, I moved to Canada at age 16 and completed my secondary education at Semiahmoo Secondary School in Surrey, BC. I then enrolled at the University of Toronto, where I graduated in June 2025 with an Honours Bachelor of Science in Computer Science and Data Science, earning High Distinction and a cumulative GPA of 3.9/4.0. I was named to the Dean’s List for five consecutive years (2020–2025) and received notable awards such as the New College In-Course Scholarship and the U of T Hatchery Fellowship.

content: My undergraduate experience was deeply enriching, extending well beyond coursework. I conducted AI research at FarDataLab under Professor Qizhen Zhang, co-founded Campus Eats under the mentorship of Professor Jack Sun, and completed a full-year co-op at Johnson Controls. I also served as President of the U of T Tutoring Club, demonstrating my dedication to leadership and community engagement. My academic coursework blended theory with application—I earned A’s in machine learning courses like CSC311 (Intro to ML), CSC412 (Probabilistic Learning), CSC413 (Neural Networks), and CSC320 (Computer Vision), applying these skills to projects such as food classification with ResNet, Inception, and VGG, as well as fine-tuning LLaMA 3.2 for chatbot development.

content: For my master’s studies, I applied to several top-tier U.S. institutions, including MIT, Stanford, Princeton, Harvard, and Yale, focusing specifically on programs specializing in artificial intelligence and machine learning. I also considered remaining in Canada and applied to the University of Toronto, where I had completed my undergraduate degree and developed strong ties within the research community. After a highly competitive admissions cycle, I was admitted to the University of Pennsylvania and chose to pursue the Master of Science in Engineering in Artificial Intelligence (MSE-AI). UPenn stood out for its balance between theoretical rigor and applied research, outstanding faculty, and close industry connections—all of which aligned perfectly with my long-term goals in machine learning.

What do you enjoy most about your program at UPenn?

content: Although I wasn’t admitted to the other schools, I found the application process to be a valuable experience that further reaffirmed my commitment to building a strong AI research profile. As I embark on my master’s journey at UPenn, I am already looking ahead to potential PhD programs. Institutions such as MIT, Stanford, UofT, Harvard, and Princeton remain top contenders due to their leadership in AI research, strong academic communities, and alignment with my personal and professional goals.

content: MIT remains a dream school for me because of its pioneering work in AI innovation and its interdisciplinary approach to research. I would be excited to contribute to MIT’s transformative work if given the opportunity. Stanford also holds strong appeal for its expertise in deep learning, NLP, and computer vision, as well as its tight integration with the Silicon Valley startup ecosystem—making it an ideal environment for someone interested in both applied research and entrepreneurship. At the University of Toronto, I have already built strong academic roots and see it as an ideal place to conduct impactful doctoral research, especially given its access to top-tier faculty such as Geoffrey Hinton and its proximity to Canadian AI hubs.

content: I also admire Harvard for its ability to bridge technical AI research with social sciences, aligning with my interests in AI ethics and policy. Princeton draws me in for its emphasis on theoretical machine learning and foundational algorithms—areas I value for their focus on rigorous thinking and elegant problem-solving. During my time at UPenn, I aim to deepen my expertise in neural network optimization, AI ethics, and efficient model training. I hope to publish in top-tier conferences, collaborate with leading researchers, and contribute to technologies that deliver social benefit. My long-term vision is to bridge academic research with real-world applications—building a career at the intersection of innovation, leadership, and impactful AI development, whether through academia, industry, or launching my own startup.

content: Mr. Zhang was my Grade 5 Math teacher and the head teacher of my class. He remains my favorite teacher and had a profound influence on my personal and academic development. What set Mr. Zhang apart was not only his exceptional ability to teach Math but also his deep empathy and attentiveness to students’ emotional well-being. He consistently observed how students were feeling—if they seemed tired or stressed, he would take us outside to play and recharge. His thoughtful and compassionate approach made learning both engaging and meaningful, and it taught me that education is as much about nurturing students as it is about delivering content. Mr. Zhang’s creativity and care left a lasting impression on me and played a significant role in shaping my values. He is one of the key reasons I have seriously considered becoming a teacher myself. Over the years, we have stayed in touch, and Mr. Zhang’s ongoing mentorship remains one of the most formative and cherished aspects of my early education.

content: I have a well-rounded and versatile technical skill set that spans mobile, web, backend, machine learning, and data engineering. In mobile app development, I primarily use Flutter to build cross-platform apps that deliver native performance and intuitive UI. I also work with Kotlin and Swift for native Android and iOS development and have past experience using React Native. For UI/UX design, I start with Figma to prototype user-friendly interfaces. In web development, I am proficient in HTML, CSS, JavaScript, and TypeScript, and use modern frameworks like React and Next.js to build responsive, interactive applications.

content: On the backend, I frequently work with Firebase—my preferred platform for its seamless integration of Firestore and Cloud Functions—and have used it extensively in projects like Campus Eats, LockIn, and DTC. I also build scalable APIs with Django and Flask, and deploy them using cloud infrastructure tools such as AWS and Google Cloud Platform. In machine learning, I specialize in both computer vision and NLP using TensorFlow and PyTorch. My workflow involves meticulous data preparation, model training, and performance optimization through techniques like hyperparameter tuning, data augmentation, and regularization. I have built and fine-tuned models including ResNet, Inception, and LLaMA 3.2, and conduct rigorous evaluation using metrics such as accuracy, precision, and recall to ensure generalizability. For data analysis and visualization, I use both Python and R.

I write efficient queries, work with JSON data, and perform data processing, cleaning, and transformation using Python for backend systems and analytics pipelines. My preferred tech stack—Flutter, Python, and JavaScript/TypeScript—enables me to switch seamlessly between mobile, backend, and frontend development, allowing me to deliver scalable, production-ready applications efficiently.

content: Beyond technical skills, I have cultivated strong business acumen through leading Campus Eats. I have conducted market research involving over 50 restaurants and 500 students, drafted detailed business plans, performed cash flow analysis, refined go-to-market strategies, and pitched at major events such as the Hatchery Dominant Pitch and the Hult Prize. These experiences strengthened my entrepreneurial mindset, market validation skills, and communication abilities. Additionally, I am fluent in both Mandarin and English—having lived in China for the first 16 years of my life and adapting quickly to English upon moving to Canada. I also plan to learn French to better engage with Canada’s bilingual culture and broaden my communication toolkit.

content: I co-founded two impactful startups aimed at enhancing student life—Campus Eats and LockIn. Campus Eats is a mobile app designed to streamline campus dining by offering discounts and significantly reducing wait times through online ordering, while LockIn motivates students to reduce phone usage by rewarding them with discounts to boost productivity. Both apps were developed from scratch and successfully pitched at prestigious competitions like the Hult Prize and the University of Toronto Hatchery, earning recognition, mentorship, and support. Campus Eats, officially registered and recognized by multiple University of Toronto programs, was built upon extensive market research involving interviews with over 50 restaurant owners and surveys of over 500 students, identifying key pain points from both sides. I led a cross-functional team of over 20 members across technology, business, media, and UI/UX design, coordinating product development, marketing strategies, launch plans, and monetization strategies involving transaction fees and premium features. These experiences honed my strong business acumen, cash flow management skills, and deep insights into balancing profitability with community benefits.

questions: What inspired you to start Campus Eats and LockIn?
How did you manage a team of over 20 people?
What are some of your startup or leadership experience?
Do you enjoy pitching and public speaking?
What’s one thing you learned about leading a startup?

content: I maintain a diverse portfolio across software engineering. Notable AI projects include StevenAI, a personalized AI chatbot fine-tuned from the 3-billion-parameter LLaMA 3.2 model using LoRA and Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG); MentorAI, which leverages mentorship videos on YouTube to generate tailored advice through large language models trained on ACL mentorship talk transcripts; AISIM, a 7-player AI social deduction simulation that studies LLM behavior through dynamic character dialogue, memory tracking, and reasoning via a Godot-powered interface; and Food101, which applied deep neural networks such as ResNet, Inception, and VGG for food category classification. I also designed and deployed an AI assistant on Raspberry Pi 5, featuring voice interaction with custom TTS models and seamless smart home integration via the Home Assistant API, supporting real-time voice feedback, touch-based interaction, and full device control. These projects are showcased through my personal website (https://liustev6.ca), built from scratch with React, Bootstrap, and Django. The site also features an interactive 3D-rendered server room crafted with Blender and Three.js, enabling dynamic exploration of my technical background and projects.

questions: Can you tell me about some personal AI projects you've built?
Which project are you most proud of so far?
What does your personal website showcase?

content: I have contributed significantly to research and industry. At FarDataLab, I participated in hardware-accelerated database research and developed novel methods to optimize data management systems by leveraging cloud hardware accelerators such as GPUs and FPGAs. This work addresses challenges posed by the end of Dennard scaling and the slowing of Moore's law, focusing on improving efficiency and scalability of data processing tasks while reducing operational costs at scale. At Jinesis Lab, I contributed to MentorAI, a research project using YouTube video links and user data to generate personalized mentorship advice by analyzing transcripts with large language models and NLP techniques. I also contributed to Johnson Controls’ home security mobile and cloud applications, integrating Google Cloud Geolocation and ChatGPT-3 for conversational device control.

questions: What kind of research have you done in AI or systems?
Have you worked on any projects in industry?

content: My backend technology choices adapt flexibly to project needs. I extensively use Firebase (Firestore and Cloud Functions) for real-time updates and scalable logic (Campus Eats, LockIn, DTC); Django with PostgreSQL for structured web applications (LandSink, personal website); Flask and FastAPI for LLM inference and vector database integrations (StevenAI, MentorAI); and AWS and GCP for GPU-accelerated inference and scalability. My mobile development expertise includes Flutter combined with Firebase, which enabled Campus Eats to evolve from a course project into a robust, fully functional, and secure application.

To ensure user-friendly designs, I conduct user interviews and surveys, follow iterative prototyping, and implement usability tests to identify and address pain points, focusing on clean, consistent UI and minimizing user friction. Customer feedback is methodically categorized into technical improvements, design changes, and feature requests, prioritized by feasibility and user impact, with ongoing acknowledgment and transparent communication of planned updates. Regular testing and feedback sessions are integral to continuous improvement.

I have experience integrating Stripe payment systems, ensuring sensitive data bypasses the backend, and is sent directly to Stripe. My projects follow clean architecture patterns for independent scaling, employing load balancers, cloud auto-scaling, optimized database queries, caching, and continuous monitoring to maintain performance and resilience as demand grows.

content: Campus Eats began as a CSC207 final project at the University of Toronto, originally conceived as a food truck ordering system built using Java and an Android frontend with a command-line interface. Although only partially implemented, this initial version laid the foundation for what would evolve into a comprehensive campus dining platform. I subsequently rebuilt Campus Eats from the ground up using Flutter and Firebase, adding extensive functionalities such as account management, shopping cart, detailed menu browsing, driver-side interfaces, and exclusive student discounts. The updated version features a redesigned UI, faster backend performance, and dedicated interfaces tailored separately for users, restaurant owners, and drivers, offering a streamlined, efficient, and affordable solution for campus dining.

questions: How did Campus Eats get started?
What changes did you make from the original version?
How did you improve performance and design?
What features does the current version of Campus Eats offer?
Was it hard to turn a class project into a real product?

content: Campus Eats addresses core issues students face with traditional food delivery apps—such as excessive wait times, high delivery fees, and limited food options. Inspired by students like Tony, a first-year student frustrated by high delivery costs and limited Asian food choices on campus, Campus Eats created the innovative Campus Grab-and-Go delivery model. This system consolidates student orders during peak hours and delivers them to central pickup locations on campus, significantly reducing costs for both students and restaurants. By offering exclusive student discounts and bulk-ordering efficiencies, Campus Eats lowers prices so students pay closer to dine-in rates rather than inflated delivery fees.

questions: What problem does Campus Eats solve for students?
How does the Grab-and-Go delivery system work?
What inspired you to create this model?
How does Campus Eats keep prices affordable?
What makes Campus Eats different from other delivery apps?

content: Restaurant owners also face challenges from existing platforms, including high commissions of up to 30% per order, which force price hikes and reduce profitability. Through extensive market research—including interviews with over 50 restaurant owners and surveys of over 500 students—I identified these critical pain points. Campus Eats resolves these by offering restaurants lower commission fees (10–15%), increased visibility to student customers, and efficient bulk ordering, enhancing profit margins without necessitating price increases.

questions: What issues do restaurant owners face with delivery apps?
How does Campus Eats support local restaurants?
What kind of market research did you do?
Why are lower commission fees important?
How does bulk ordering help restaurant partners?

content: Campus Eats provides a modern, intuitive user interface, making it easy for students to explore dining options via integrated maps and place secure orders through seamless Stripe-powered payment processing. The app ensures robust security measures, including two-factor authentication and encrypted card handling, with smooth address management facilitated by Google Cloud Maps integration. Users benefit from flexible ordering options—pickup, direct delivery, or the Campus Grab-and-Go system—with live order tracking and built-in chat functions enhancing communication between users, vendors, and drivers.

questions: What features does Campus Eats offer for students?
How does the app handle payments and security?
Can users track their orders in real time?
What are the ordering options in the app?
Is it easy to navigate and use for new students?

content: Vendor-side functionalities are equally comprehensive, allowing restaurant owners to manage storefronts, dynamically create nested menu structures, and instantly receive payments via Stripe Connect. An intuitive vendor onboarding system simplifies the launch process, helping restaurants quickly go live and seamlessly integrate banking information. Additionally, the platform incorporates Algolia-powered search features for convenient browsing by vendor name, food type, or category.

questions: What tools do restaurants get with Campus Eats?
How easy is it for a vendor to get started?
Can vendors customize their menus?

content: Under my leadership, Campus Eats grew significantly, involving contributions of over 30,000 lines of code and effective coordination of a 20-person multidisciplinary team spanning mobile and web development, business strategy, and UI/UX design. I spearheaded the startup’s participation in prestigious entrepreneurial programs such as the University of Toronto Hatchery fellowship and pitched at competitions like the Hatchery Dominant Pitch and Hult Prize. Through mentorship from industry experts like Erica Barra, I refined my entrepreneurial and leadership skills, developed detailed cash flow projections, and crafted a sustainable business model.

questions: What was your role in leading Campus Eats?
How big was your team and how did you manage it?

content: Feedback from users has been overwhelmingly positive, highlighting Campus Eats’ intuitive interface and time-saving features, with constructive suggestions for improvements like faster processing during peak hours and expanded dietary customization options. I actively leverage such feedback, maintaining ongoing communication with users and restaurant partners to continuously refine and align the app with user needs. Campus Eats remains my favorite and most challenging project, deepening my understanding of customer needs, entrepreneurship complexities, and effective team management.

questions: What do users say about Campus Eats?
How do you gather and apply user feedback?
What improvements have users asked for?
What did you learn from building Campus Eats?
Why is this project meaningful to you?

content: Campus Eats’ innovative model has been validated by strong market interest: 72% of students surveyed expressed willingness to use a fairly-priced campus delivery service, and restaurant owners indicated the platform’s potential for improved profitability and market reach. With revenue streams from commissions, memberships, and in-app advertising—and carefully managed operational costs—Campus Eats projects profitability with a break-even threshold of just 30–40 daily orders per location.

questions: Did students and restaurants like the Campus Eats idea?
How was the market interest measured?
What revenue streams does the app use?
How many daily orders are needed to break even?
Why was this model seen as sustainable?

content: Founded in May 2023 by myself, Tom, Emma, and Kevin, Campus Eats has ambitious expansion goals. Initially launching pickup hubs at the UTSG campus, the startup plans to expand across Ontario campuses by 2025, enter additional Canadian regions by 2026, and eventually target high schools, offices, and residential neighborhoods. With a sizeable serviceable obtainable market of $18.25 million at U of T alone, $44.3 million across Canadian colleges, and a North American total available market of $4.75 billion, Campus Eats aims to revolutionize campus dining continent-wide, offering better food, greater affordability, and enhanced quality of life for students everywhere.

questions: Who founded Campus Eats?
Where did Campus Eats first launch?
What are the future expansion plans?
What’s the size of the market you’re targeting?
What’s the long-term vision for Campus Eats?

content: We paused our projects in 2025 due to several key challenges. First, our Grab-and-Go business model relied on a large initial user base—essential for restaurants to remain profitable after offering discounts and for us to cover delivery, platform, and staffing costs. Second, with growing emphasis on diversity and fairness, we aimed to onboard a wider range of restaurants, but couldn’t ensure enough demand to justify discounted pricing for all partners. Third, health-related regulations from the university limited the sale of food from external vendors on campus. Looking ahead, we plan to pivot toward a flexible coupon-based model that supports not only restaurants but also other vendors seeking to reach the student market through tiered discounts. Campus Ease will manage student verification and offer subscription-based premium tiers for partners. While we will preserve the original dining functionalities of Campus Eats, this expanded vision reflects our goal to make Campus Ease a broader platform for student-focused savings and campus engagement.

questions: Why was Campus Eats paused in 2025?
What challenges did you face with the original model?
What is the new direction for the platform?
What’s the idea behind Campus Ease?
Will the original dining features still be available?

For convenience and self-development, I shifted the project to React.js with Bootstrap in 2023, introducing a major UI update with cyber-casual styles. In 2025, I redesigned it again with cyber neon colors, giving it a slightly more professional look and adding more animations and sections. New features include the built-in 3D server room with Three.js, a two-column gallery with varying scroll speeds, and other interactive elements.

content: During my co-op at Johnson Controls, I worked as a full-stack mobile app developer under the guidance of my supervisor, Praharsh Bhatt, and manager, Rajmy Sayavong. I contributed to the development of a smart home and community management app called DTC (also known as Community). The app was built using Flutter for the frontend and Firebase for the backend, with cloud functions written in TypeScript. I was also responsible for designing the user interface in Figma and implementing the UI into a fully functional and responsive mobile app.

metadata.section: section about coop at Johnson Controls

content: The app featured several core functionalities. Users could create and manage different types of circles—private circles, community circles, and home circles—where they could invite others, assign roles, and manage shared chats, devices, and announcements. We integrated an AI-powered assistant bot that could help users navigate the app or control smart devices simply by sending a message or speaking. The bot supported both speech-to-text and text-to-speech, enabling users to have voice-based conversations with the assistant. Additionally, users could add smart devices to their circles and create automation routines between devices.

metadata.section: section about coop at Johnson Controls

content: On the integration side, I worked on connecting the app to Google Cloud Platform APIs to enable real-time geolocation tracking for people and devices within each circle. We also integrated support for smart home protocols like Google Matter and Zigbee through our implementation of the Flutter Home Assistant SDK. This allowed users to remotely control devices and automate interactions within their smart environments, all through a central cloud database

content: This co-op provided me with valuable hands-on experience in full-stack mobile development, real-time cloud integration, and smart home technologies. I deepened my skills in UI/UX design, mobile UI implementation, backend logic with cloud functions, API integrations, and building intelligent assistants with voice interaction. The project was both technically challenging and rewarding, giving me a well-rounded understanding of modern connected app ecosystems.

content: LockIn, also known as aSocial, is a productivity-focused mobile and web application that I co-founded to help students reduce phone usage and improve their time management. The app is built around a simple but effective concept: when users “lock in” their phones, they earn rewards based on the duration of their screen-free time. These rewards can then be redeemed for discounts at nearby businesses, creating a tangible incentive for students to stay off their devices. LockIn not only helps students save time and improve focus, but also supports local merchants by increasing student engagement with discount-based foot traffic.

questions: What is LockIn (aSocial) and what problem does it solve?
How does LockIn encourage students to stay off their phones?
What kind of rewards can users earn through LockIn?
Why did you choose to focus on student productivity?
How does LockIn benefit local businesses?

content: The app features a reward system powered by the integration of iOS Screen Time APIs, allowing for accurate tracking of phone usage. It maintains a local-vendor reward database so students can exchange their earned time for discounts, contributing to a 30% average reduction in screen time among active users. LockIn is available as both a mobile app and a web platform. The mobile version was developed using Swift for iOS and Flutter for UI refinement, while the web version was built using Next.js. Firebase was integrated to enable real-time updates and seamless user experience across platforms.

questions: How does LockIn measure phone usage accurately?

content: As a founding engineer, I played a central role in prototyping, developing, and launching the app on both the Apple Store and the web. I provided technical leadership across all parts of the stack, working on frontend and backend systems, reward tracking, and real-time infrastructure. My work included developing user-facing interfaces, implementing backend logic, and integrating key technologies like Firebase and iOS APIs. I also helped refine the product strategy to ensure it aligned with student needs and vendor partnerships.

The project has demonstrated strong impact, with measurable improvements in user focus and time management, and continues to expand its reach among student communities and local businesses.

content: I have served as a Research Assistant at the University of Toronto since September 2023, contributing to cutting-edge research in both large language models (LLMs) and hardware-accelerated database systems through my work with Jinesis Lab and FarDataLab. My interdisciplinary projects focus on optimizing computational systems for real-world applications in education, infrastructure, and machine learning. Guided by Professors Zhijing Jin and Qizhen Zhang, I blend theoretical insight with system-level engineering to advance AI for social good and improve database efficiency at scale.

questions: What kind of research do you do at the University of Toronto?
Who are your research supervisors?
How is Qizhen Zhang and Zhijing Jin?
How do you contribute to AI for social good?
How are LLMs and database systems connected in your work?

content: At Jinesis Lab, under the supervision of Zhijing Jin, I led the development of an LLM-powered mentorship chatbot (MentorAI) designed to help students navigate research planning by synthesizing knowledge from the ACL Mentorship Channel. My work involved building multiple video-to-chatbot pipelines using advanced components such as LLM summarizers, transcript-based Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG), supervised fine-tuning, and prompt engineering. I conducted evaluations across leading models including Qwen-2.5 and LLaMA-3, contributing to the lab’s broader mission of applying LLMs to promote equity and accessibility in academic mentorship.

questions: What is MentorAI and how does it work?
How did you apply LLMs to mentorship support?
Which models did you evaluate in this project?
What is the goal of the Jinesis Lab?
How does your chatbot support academic equity and accessibility?

content: At FarDataLab, under the guidance of Qizhen Zhang, I worked on accelerated database management systems aimed at overcoming performance limitations of general-purpose processors caused by the end of Dennard scaling and Moore’s Law. I designed and deployed three 5-node PrestoDB clusters configured with various combinations of GPU and FPGA hardware. I conducted extended TPC-H benchmark queries (lasting over 12 hours) to evaluate system performance, ultimately identifying a GPU-only configuration that delivered a 20% improvement in query throughput. This work contributes to the growing field of hardware-software co-design in large-scale cloud data systems.

questions: What kind of research did you do at FarDataLab?
How did you use GPU and FPGA for database acceleration?
What was the goal of your PrestoDB cluster experiments?
What performance improvements did you observe?
How does this research contribute to cloud data systems?

content: My future research vision is driven by two major goals. First, I aim to deepen my understanding of low-level optimization for LLM training, inspired by hands-on experience configuring Unsloth for resource-efficient fine-tuning. I have successfully used LoRA adapters to merge models up to 11 billion parameters on a 16GB VRAM GPU, making advanced LLM research feasible in home lab environments. Questions such as why tools like Unsloth lack multi-GPU support motivate me to pursue deeper research in system efficiency, ideally at MIT using its world-class infrastructure. My goal is to publish impactful work that makes LLM training accessible to independent developers. Second, I am passionate about applied AI in industry, focusing on lightweight, verticalized models that achieve high accuracy for specialized tasks and are deployable locally, pushing forward the boundary of practical, secure, and scalable AI.

questions: What are your long-term research goals?
How did your experience with Unsloth shape your interest?
Why is system efficiency in LLMs important to you?
What motivates you to focus on lightweight and verticalized models?
How do you plan to contribute to practical and scalable AI?

content: The Food-101 Image Classification Project is a deep learning–based system designed to automatically identify and categorize food images into 22 distinct classes, such as sushi, ramen, pizza, and dumplings. It leverages the widely-used Food-101 dataset, which contains thousands of labeled food images, as a foundation for training and evaluating models. The goal of the project is to build an accurate and efficient image classification pipeline capable of handling real-world food photos with varied lighting, angles, and compositions.

questions: What is the Food-101 Image Classification Project?
How many food categories does your model recognize?
Why did you choose the Food-101 dataset for this project?
What real-world challenges does the model handle?
What was the main goal of building this classification system?

content: At its core, the project involves fine-tuning convolutional neural networks (CNNs) such as ResNet, Inception, and VGG. These pre-trained models are adapted using techniques like transfer learning, data augmentation, and hyperparameter tuning to improve performance and robustness. Beyond just model training, the project explores practical challenges in computer vision—like handling class imbalance, avoiding overfitting, and ensuring generalization through careful validation.

questions: Which deep learning models did you use in the Food-101 project?
What techniques did you apply to improve model performance?
How did you deal with overfitting in this project?
What role does data augmentation play in your pipeline?
Why did you fine-tune models like ResNet or Inception instead of training from scratch?

content: From a user perspective, the project offers an interactive demo hosted at https://www.liustev6.ca/foodImageClassify, where users can upload a food image and receive a predicted category. This not only showcases the model's capabilities but also makes the system accessible and engaging for non-technical users. Overall, the Food-101 Image Classification Project demonstrates how machine learning can be applied to everyday tasks—like recognizing meals from images—while serving as a platform for experimenting with modern deep learning techniques. For me personally, this project marked my first experience building an advanced machine learning system. It introduced me to frequently-used deep learning architectures and helped me become familiar with state-of-the-art neural network techniques, forming a strong foundation for my future work in AI.

questions: Where can people try out your Food-101 demo?
What does the interactive demo do?
How did this project help you grow in machine learning?
What was your biggest takeaway from building this system?
How does this project show the real-world value of deep learning?

content: StevenAI is a personalized AI chatbot built to answer questions specifically about my life, projects, skills, and background. It was initially created by fine-tuning a large language model (LLaMA 3.2) and later enhanced with a custom Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) layer to overcome the limitations of fine-tuning alone. StevenAI represents a hybrid system that merges parameter-efficient fine-tuning with semantic search–based retrieval to provide more accurate, flexible, and personalized responses. It can run on either the original fine-tuned LLaMA model or external models like ChatGPT-4, allowing users to compare and explore different answer qualities based on model architecture and context dependency.

questions: What is StevenAI and what does it do?
Why did you create a personalized AI chatbot?
What models power StevenAI?
How does StevenAI combine fine-tuning and retrieval?
Can users choose between different model backends when using StevenAI?

content: StevenAI is a personalized AI chatbot that I created by fine-tuning the LLaMA 3.2 model, which contains over 3 billion parameters. To build it, I developed a 1,000 Q&A custom dataset about myself, including my projects, experiences, academic background, and personal interests. This dataset was used to train a LoRA (Low-Rank Adaptation) adapter on my personal server, which was then merged with the base LLaMA 3.2 model to form the final chatbot.

questions: How did you build the original version of StevenAI?
What kind of data did you use to fine-tune LLaMA 3.2?
How big was your fine-tuned dataset for StevenAI?
What’s a LoRA adapter and how did you use it?

content: While the original chatbot captured a wide range of personal details, I encountered multiple issues. Large models (like 8B) frequently surfaced unrelated pretraining noise, overshadowing fine-tuned responses. Conversely, smaller models (like 3B) lacked capacity, resulting in frequent errors such as mixing up friends’ names. Moreover, to emphasize key facts, the dataset included duplicated questions, which led to repetitive, overemphasized answers and reduced memory allocation for lower-priority facts.

questions: What issues did you face when fine-tuning large models?
Why didn’t the 3B and 8B models work well for StevenAI?
How did repeated questions affect the model’s output?
What kinds of mistakes did StevenAI make without RAG?
Why wasn’t fine-tuning alone enough for your chatbot?

content: To address these challenges, I added a Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) layer. This upgrade uses bge-large-en-v1.5 to embed content and stores it in a FAISS index. The knowledge base was completely restructured: instead of using duplicated Q&A pairs, I rewrote the data into concise fact chunks, each appearing only once. When a user sends a question, the system performs two types of retrieval: (1) a top-3 direct fact match, and (2) a top-3 question match, based on five auto-generated sample questions per fact chunk. Only question embeddings are stored in the RAG index, with the corresponding answers saved in the metadata. The final prompt includes these six retrieved contexts before being passed to the chatbot.

questions: How does the RAG layer improve StevenAI?
What is stored in the FAISS index?
Why did you restructure the knowledge base into fact chunks?
How are questions matched during retrieval?
What model did you use for text embedding?

content: StevenAI’s RAG-enhanced prompt can be passed to either the original fine-tuned LLaMA 3.2 model or a general-purpose model like ChatGPT-4. Each option has its trade-offs: the fine-tuned LLaMA model has strong internal knowledge about me but is limited in dynamic fact retrieval, while ChatGPT-4 depends entirely on the retrieved RAG context and performs better when interpreting semantically complex or rare questions. Users can try both models side-by-side at https://www.liustev6.ca to explore the strengths of each setup.

questions: What are the pros and cons of using LLaMA vs. ChatGPT-4 for StevenAI?
How does StevenAI decide which model to use?
Can users try both models in your demo?
When is ChatGPT-4 better than the fine-tuned model?
How does your system combine RAG with model prompting?

content: LandSink is a predictive analytics project I developed during my CSC110 course, aimed at estimating future global temperatures and the percentage of land that may be submerged due to rising sea levels. The model is built using linear regression and trained on global datasets of sea level, temperature, and elevation. Originally implemented using Pygame, the early version generated HTML output for each prediction. Later, I upgraded the project by building a Django back-end hosted on AWS, allowing users to make predictions via API requests. Users can interact with the live prediction tool at [https://www.liustev6.ca/landSink](https://www.liustev6.ca/landSink). My responsibilities included collecting and cleaning data, building the regression model, and modernizing the tech stack for scalable, web-based access. The project tackles real-world environmental forecasting while serving as a hands-on application of regression modeling, data integration, and full-stack deployment.

questions: What is the LandSink project and what does it predict?
Why did you build LandSink and how did it evolve from CSC110?
How does your prediction model estimate land submersion?
Can people try the LandSink tool online?
What technologies did you use to build and deploy LandSink?

content: My data science showcasing website, built using Rmarkdown, serves as a central hub for a diverse range of projects that highlight my skills in data analysis, machine learning, and visualization using tools like R and Python. Among the featured projects is an NBA2K player rating prediction model, which uses linear regression based on players’ regular-season statistics to estimate their ratings in future NBA2K game editions. Another project applies natural language processing (NLP) to analyze Clash Royale players’ sentiment toward game updates, extracting emotional trends from player responses.

content: I have also visualized theft patterns in Toronto, highlighting temporal and geographic trends using data visualization techniques. In another project, I explored the relationship between life expectancy and alcohol consumption, uncovering public health correlations through statistical analysis. Additionally, my Great Lakes Pollution analysis focuses on phosphorus contamination, using time series plots and interactive maps to visualize water quality data sourced from The Canadian Open Data Portal. Altogether, the website demonstrates my ability to apply machine learning models, perform insightful analyses, and communicate findings effectively through compelling visualizations.

content: I built a powerful 2-node personal server from scratch to support a wide range of projects—from web hosting and cloud storage to machine learning and remote gaming. Designed for flexibility and performance, one node runs 24/7 for lightweight tasks, while the other handles GPU-intensive workloads like fine-tuning models and LLM hosting. Both nodes run Proxmox and use containers and VMs for efficient workload management. This setup powers my apps like StevCloud and StevenAI and serves as a hands-on platform for learning system architecture, DevOps, and cloud infrastructure.

questions: What kind of server setup do you use for your projects?
Why did you choose a two-node architecture?
How do you manage different types of workloads across your server?
What kinds of projects run on your server?
What role does your server play in your learning and development?

content: The first node is a lightweight, always-on host that ensures continuous availability for development tasks, real-time web services, and light machine learning jobs. It features an AMD Ryzen 7 5800X CPU, NVIDIA GeForce RTX 4060 Ti GPU, 32GB Corsair Vengeance RGB Pro DDR4 RAM at 3600MHz, and storage with a 1TB Samsung 990 EVO SSD paired with a 4TB Seagate IronWolf Pro HDD. The system is built on an ASUS TUF Gaming B550-PLUS Wi-Fi II motherboard, cooled with a Thermalright Peerless Assassin 120 SEARGB cooler, and housed in a Corsair iCUE 4000D RGB Airflow case with additional RGB fans for thermal performance and aesthetics. It’s powered by a Corsair RM750e PSU, recently upgraded to a Thermaltake GF3 1200W PSU for overhead and future expansions.

questions: What are the specs of your always-on server node?
Why did you choose the Ryzen 7 5800X and RTX 4060 Ti for Node 1?
How do you keep your server cool and power-efficient?
What types of tasks run on your first server node?
Did you face any challenges when building this node?

content: The second node is a high-performance, power-intensive machine used selectively for heavier tasks like fine-tuning large language models, hosting LLM inference servers (e.g., StevenAI base model), and remote gaming via GPU passthrough. This dual-boot system switches between Proxmox and Windows depending on the task and remains off when not in use to conserve power. It features an AMD Ryzen 9 9950X CPU, NVIDIA GeForce RTX 5090 with 32GB VRAM, 96GB Asgard x TUF Strix DDR5 RAM, a Samsung 990 Pro 4TB SSD, and a Kingston NV3 1TB SSD. The core is mounted on a ProArt X870E-Creator motherboard, making it ideal for content creation, deep learning training, and AI hosting.

questions: What do you use your second high-performance node for?
Why does your second node dual boot between Proxmox and Windows?
What are the specs and components of your high-performance machine?
How do you handle GPU-intensive workloads on this setup?
When do you turn on your second node?

content: Both systems run Proxmox as the primary OS for virtualization and container management. I use containers and VMs to deploy applications like the backend for my personal website, StevCloud (a self-hosted personal file storage service), and a Windows VM for remote gaming, enabling me to stream high-performance games to any device. Networking is configured via Cloudflare to securely manage web traffic and remote access.

questions: What operating system do you use for virtualization?

content: My home lab server reflects my deep interest in server architecture, DevOps, cloud infrastructure, and AI development. Managing my own infrastructure gives me full control over system resources, lets me experiment with virtual environments, and hones my skills in system administration and distributed deployment. The setup’s flexibility, raw power, and educational value make it a central part of my development and research workflow.

content: StevCloud is my self-hosted personal cloud server, built using NextCloud, an open-source cloud software platform. It is hosted on my own home server, giving me full control over my cloud infrastructure and data privacy. The system is backed by a 4TB Seagate IronWolf Pro HDD, providing ample and reliable storage capacity for my photos, learning materials, important documents, and media files. Accessible at https://cloud.liustev6.ca, StevCloud allows me to seamlessly access and manage my data from anywhere while also enabling secure file sharing. Because it’s fully self-hosted, I avoid reliance on third-party cloud providers and retain full autonomy over system configuration, security, and performance.

content: AISIM (AI Simulation Game) is an 7-player AI-powered social deduction game designed for research on large language model (LLM) behavior. The game simulates complex multi-agent interactions where each AI character engages in dialogue, tracks memory, and reasons toward hidden goals. AISIM connects to a 2D pixel-style Godot frontend, which renders real-time character portraits, dynamic conversations, and group chat scenes, creating an immersive and visually engaging environment. The backend is built using FastAPI and SQLite, enabling modular simulation of game rounds, conversation flows, and persistent player state management. AISIM integrates multiple LLMs—using LLaMA for real-time character dialogues and Deepseek for memory updates and strategic reasoning. Role-specific system prompts and contextual memory logs are employed to generate unique, goal-oriented behavior for each AI player. This setup allows researchers to explore how different LLMs interact, adapt strategies, and simulate social behavior in a controlled, game-like setting.

questions: What is AISIM and how does it work?
Why did you build a simulation game with LLMs?
How do different AI agents interact in AISIM?
What kind of research can AISIM support?
What tools and frameworks did you use to build AISIM?

content: DIY AI Assistant is a personal, self-built voice assistant system deployed on a Raspberry Pi 5, designed for everyday use in my home. It serves as both a smart home control hub and an LLM-powered conversational assistant that I can talk to naturally. I use it to control lights, open doors with sensor triggers, and interact with my smart environment simply by speaking—like saying “turn on the light” or “open the door.” The assistant features a custom text-to-speech engine for natural voice responses and connects to all my smart devices via the Home Assistant API. I also built a real-time GUI using Kivy, which provides live voice feedback, touch control, and a smooth interface for managing devices. Beyond automation, it’s my playground for hardware exploration and AI experimentation, offering me a compact, open-source alternative to commercial systems—fully tailored to my needs, fully under my control.

questions: What does your DIY AI Assistant do?
Why did you choose to build your own voice assistant?
How do you use your assistant to control your home?
What hardware and software power your voice assistant?
How is your assistant different from commercial systems like Alexa?
